Title: Linking forum posts - neuralnets-07-T1.1
Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructorâ€™s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.threadtitle: Unexplained terminology issue
Input.posts:
Again and again the lectures introduce and make use of unexplained terms. I find this incredibly inefficient and frustrating, as I'm repeating the same part of a lecture many times, trying to figure out what I'm (supposedly) missing. As reasonable as such a problem is, I've never encountered such a problem of this magnitude in any course in the past (online or otherwise). It come to a point I open a google tab and a dictionary tab, along with the lecture by reflex. Unfortunately even that often fails to help me investigate 'what did he mean?' . I'm feeling like this from the beginning of the course, but I thought it will be impolite of me to risk offending a staff which is actually doing me a favor by teaching me something for free, and besides I trusted that eventually this issue will be resolved, I'm truly grateful for this course, but like my sister once said to me once when see sensed my feedback to one of her drawings was too *filtered*: 'spare my next drawing, not my feelings', I feel this issue should be addressed not only for the benefit of the students but for the staff as well. I'm threading this now after encountering the term 'state' in lecture 7a where I had little idea as for what it could mean, I became sure it means 'activation' (values) at lecture 7b up to about 5:00 in, but that theory got blown out of the water by the next slide where 'activations' were used in a way suggesting a reference to something else. Unfortunately this term is as mentioned just one of many undefined terms such as: 'delay taps' which I'm guessing refers to index offsets. 'teaching signal' probably means 'target value' (IMHO). 'objective function' almost definitely (IMHO) refers to the hypothesis function, but actually means cost function (site's forum). 'filter' was actually 1st introduced in the quiz where I guessed it to be 'feature duplication map'. 'fan-in' apparently this is used in electronics too (google). 'utterance' - 'sentence' (online dictionary). 'number & tense' - some 'utterance' terminology I presume. ... If any of these term was actually defined properly, than I apologize in advance, but as I have a very good memory, and I summarize pretty much everything with great detail, I'm mostly confidant of this list. Actually I found many lectures hard to understand even when the above problem didn't occur, but I too fond it hard to explain exactly what I'm referring to. My suggestions: 1. Take more care regarding new terms. 2. Use 'like', 'unlike', and 'for instance' when introducing new ideas. 3. Take notes regarding the way others explain similar/same material ([example][1]). 4. Record the lectures with live audience, even just 1 person who isn't familiar with the material and truly wants to learn, should be enough to stop and ask 'what do you mean' or ask for a different explanation or example, during the lecture so it may be edited accordingly, until it is perfectly clear. 5. Lookout for new / highly-rated threads in the 'lectures' category. I hope this tread will be only considered as constructive criticism, and won't offend anyone. Thank you for reading my thread (for this long), and thank you for this course (I'm learning a lot ^^). [1]: https://class.coursera.org/ml-2012-002/class/index

People experiment with this simplification of learning and they call this NNs with random hidden layer ELM, Extreme Lerning Machines. Is it a promising method or is it stuck with the regularization problems? Does the Barron's paper [Universal approximation bounds for superpositions of sigmoidal function,1993] directly applies to this kind of model? If yes, it's useless in high dimensional problems.
